bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frederick L. Rath, Jr., February 11, 1952

div1.p: Hench informs Rath of renewed efforts by the Cubans to preserve Camp Lazear, but still believes American help will improve the situation. He requests advice on preserving another Cuban building, whose owners will not entrust its care to the Cuban government.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frederick L. Rath, Jr., February 11, 1952
div1.opener:
February 11, 1952
Mr. Frederick L. Rath, Jr., Director
National Council for Historic Sites and Buildings
712 Jackson Place N.W.
Washington 6, D.C.
My dear Mr. Rath:
div1.p:
I have just returned from Cuba and am anxious to report to you and General
Grant regarding the status of Walter Reed's little experimental building.
It would appear that the Cubans are actually going to do something and the
architect from the Ministry of Health gave me a copy of a blue print which
shows what they plan to do. It is not adequate but at the moment they only
have $25,000 alotted to the project. I am sure American help will be neces-
sary to improve the situation. But at long last the Cubans seem to have
broken through their 10-year inortia and I am much more hopeful that a co-
operative effort will accomplish what I have been hoping for for so long.

There is another building much more valuable, concerning which two Cuban
friends asked my advice. It is a lovely Cuban Finca, in a suburb of Havana,
the owners of which have been collecting Cuban objets d'art for some years
and which they wish to have preserved. They hope to give it to an appropriate
group which will look after it but have no faith in the Cuban Government and
do not want to have any governmental body administer it. They have asked me
if I could find out if there is any Cuban-American association interested in
such matters. They knew of none, although they have lived in Havana all of
their lives. However this is a matter which is secondary to my favorite
project.

I received your kind letter of January 21, forwarded to me in Havana, and I
shall be delighted to lunch with you and General Grant; however I fear that
I did not make myself clear in my last letter to you. I thought I had stated
I would have an all-day meeting at Bethesda (U. S. Public Health Service)
on Saturday, February 23 and proposed lunch either Friday, the 22nd or Sunday
the 24, suggesting however that Sunday might be an important day of rest for
both you and General Grant. I would appreciate it greatly if you could let
me know whether I could see you and General Grant, preferably for lunch or
possibly for dinner, Friday the 22nd. I must make my pullman reservations and
hotel reservations at once. I have tentative reservations at the Mayflower.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
